commentBody:
My five favorite original clues from last week
(in order of appearance):

1. Ones getting good marks?  (3)7)
2. Sage-colored sage  (4)
3. Pilot returning to the air, e.g.  (5)
4. Plant energy source  (7)
5. Pet sitter?  (3)(3)


CON ARTISTS
YODA
RERUN
URANIUM
LAP CAT

(Second try)

(in order of appearance):

No joke, this is a delightful Monday puzzle. 

Congratulations, Ken and Stacy, on a cracking good debut.

i thought the theme was cute, but i was frustrated by the crossings with names- VIGODA/IMPEI had me stuck for a while and so did STP/TERI. i‚Äôm always bummed when i have to look stuff up on a monday.

Which will be the most common nit picked today?

The appropriateness of Fuzzy Wuzzy in a crossword puzzle

or

The ‚Äúfact‚Äù that segments of SNL are correctly called ‚Äúsketches‚Äù, not SKITS.

I'm not sayin' it's *easy*, and I'm sure I haven't calculated the area under that curve in, oh, 35 years, but-- --do we really need to go back to the days of: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DDxmpUQfBWs ?

Puzzle Haiku:

What's cracking, Ono?
The Lads on the radio:
apnea, again.

***

He is Moscow's mule,
our knucklehead "Godfather."
Goals? Shed IRS.

***

Luna bends, loops, veers,
a paler acai berry,
hard shard of Miro.

***

(and a limerick)

There was a pet emu named Luna
who gnawed out of her cage in Cancuna.
She spread bird influenza
to the wise folks from Mensa
whose brains were then filled with lacuna.

I'll see myself out!

25D and 44A clues go together like a what do they have in common joke.
The clue ‚Äúgap‚Äù was near laconic for my simple brain, have to continue a search for the $10 reference.

Wasn‚Äôt a fan of VIGODA and ALDA crossing, had me stuck for several minutes at the end. 

135 Mondays in a row! Woohoo!
Well done you two! I hope Ken's mom made an exception and did the puzzle. Keep up the good work.

So many unknowns for me, especially for a Monday... I also did not get the theme, at all. It was just too abstract for me. Even having read the column I needed a moment to grasp the explanation. My mind just did not want to make the leap of understanding how you can crack an eggplant. Yes, I know it was about cracking an egg, but in my head eggplant is eggplant: I just don't see the egg there, and there are few things as uncrackable as an eggplant ü§™. Even though it was all spelled out in the column, I needed a good 10 or 20 seconds to process it.

Before reading the column I ended up checking the puzzle - yes, on Monday - when I did not get my gold star. I stared at the grid and I just gave up.

Turns out chUCKLEHEAD was wrong. Having that exactly same length synonym there rather than KNUCKLEHEAD was an unfortunate result of, first, my lack of understanding of the theme, and second, Andrzej-unfriendly crosses. So how did I not see that mistake?

The c rather than K came from an answer to the SNL clue - I automatically ignore SNL clues because I almost never know the answer to them (today it was gettable, after all, but what of it - my mind was a slave to its "we ignore SNL rule"). The h rather than N was a cross with some band I've never heard of.

Solving in the middle of the night, after 3 hours of sleep, may have been a factor in my failure. I'll try to go back to sleep now and forget about this unpleasant experience.
Congratulations on your first puzzle, Ken and Stacy!

Had an hour nap in the middle of solving this. Unscheduled naps are one reason I don't worry about my times or averages.
Gap is not what I thought LACUNA meant. Now I will have to think on what word I've been confusing it with. No, not viCUNA. 
Always nice to see our friend IM PEI.
Recently rewatched a few episodes of Barney Miller. Holds up pretty well. I think Mr. VIGODA was in The Godfather, too.
Alan ALDA's first memoir, Never Have Your Dog Stuffed, is entertaining.  His parents were vaudeville performers and the showgirls* would often keep an eye on him.

*Would you believe that Autocorrect wanted to change this to showers?????
Congratulations on a breezy NYT debut, Mr. Cohen and Ms Cooper! Nicely done!

Asymmetric encryption is the cure for the common code.

(I got a loud cipher that one.)

Why are words in the puzzle not acceptable in comments?

I have posted a comment three (3) times over the past hour.  So far, not here.

I‚Äôm surprised there aren‚Äôt a bunch of complaints about all the proper names. (Ten; thirteen if you count the clues containing proper names!) They happened to be names I knew, so not a problem for me.  My only hesitation was what to do with the two extra squares for la di da.
From the crafters' comments, TIL that Woodrow Wilson had been married twice, and his first wife's name was Ellen.   That would screw up the puzzle for me when Edith didn't fit.
"Bedwetting" didn't fit.

When my kids have problem with the eggs:

Tri cracking.

I had a CRACKING good time with this puzzle, but I wasn't able to CRACK what connected the themers, so the revealer delivered a nice aha. And as someone who still listens to the RADIO, I'm singing along with Freddie,"RADIO whats new, someone still loves you" (yes, *that* Freddie, the one who, at Live Aid 1985, CRACKed the CODE on how rock concerts are meant to be done https://youtu.be/o-0ygW-B_gI?si=KskQBKrW6XKT72q6) Congratulations, Mr. Cohen and Ms. Cooper, on a very nice d√©but!

A fun puzzle with more meat than a usual for a Monday. I liked the theme, but unlike yesterday's, knowing the theme didn't help me solve the puzzle. In fact, I forgot to even look at it until I was done and read the column. 

VIGODA and ALDA took me back to being 12-years-old, sitting on my grandmother's orange shag carpet, doing a puzzle from one of her magazines that smelled like cigarette smoke while listening to Tony Orlando on her 8-track. Those two names were in so many puzzles back then.

I always thought a KNUCKLEHEAD was a stubborn person who did the same dumb things over and over again, but that's probably because my grandfather used to call my brother that when he got in trouble for doing some dumb thing over and over again. By contrast, I thought a goofball was someone who did silly things on purpose for a laugh, but the online dictionaries don't all agree on that, and anyway, the clue is close enough. 

I thought the cross of 15A and 6D were going to be a Natick for me because I didn't know IM PEI and assumed that groupies of My Chemical Romance called themselves by some specific name, but that was only because I missed the "e.g." in the clue. With the rest of the crosses, I could see the answer was just a description, which was easy to suss when only the M in EMOFAN was left.

Weirdly, EGGPLANTDIP took a lot of crosses. I must be tired because I kept thinking, "Wait. What do eggs have to do with baba ghanouj?" That was a real "Duh" moment.

I‚Äôm usually not one of the complainers, but this is probably the first Monday I‚Äôve seen with a genuine Natick. VIGODA crossing IMPEI and ALDA? I didn‚Äôt struggle with them, but it feels meaner than a typical Monday would be.
I don't think I've ever said "What's cracking?" Maybe it's a regional thing.
Sam, I'm with you 100% on knuckle cracking. It makes my ears hurt.

Nice Monday puzzle. Most of it filled in just from the clues and then a few things had to work out from the crosses. And didn't entirely catch on to the theme until I was almost done. That's a nice touch. Puzzle find today was one of the strangest I've ever encountered. I can't even describe it. Eight 23 letter grid-spanning theme answers. A Sunday from May 17, 1998 by David J. Kahn and Hillary B. Kahn with the tile "Green eggs and Hamlet." Just one sample answer: OOPSISTABBEDOPHELIASDAD Here's the Xword info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/17/1998&g=65&d=A I'm done.

Clever theme and great debut, congrats to you both. 

I knew it but was surprised by LACUNA in an early week offering.  How did I know it?  The Kingsolver novel (2009) was laying around here for the longest time.  Probably a book club loan from a neighbor.  Now I'll have to find it and read it.
Always nice to have an excellent first puzzle from friends, and hope to see more from Stacy and Ken.

I found there were a few too many proper nouns today, with trivia that is entirely obscure to me‚Ä¶ so naturally, a rather frustrating solve. That being said - I thought the theme was funny and it got a chuckle out of me, so all in all, an OK Monday :)

While solving today‚Äôs puzzle, the roller coaster seemed to be having a fun time.

And Teri echoed crackpot.

Strands, an easy Monday.
No spoilers, plz, before "view all replies"

Strands #407
‚ÄúApril showers ...‚Äù
üü°üîµüîµüîµ
üîµüîµüîµ

Easy for me, anyway, and a welcome respite from taxes.

Random thoughts:
‚Ä¢	This puzzle got me to thinking about things that you can crack, and there‚Äôs nuts, safes, ice, riddles, jokes, books, and smiles.  Any more?
‚Ä¢	Lovely answers today in SHARD, LACUNA, and HAIKU.
‚Ä¢	When I think of memorable books, Barbarba Kingsolver‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Lacuna‚Äù, always pops up in my head.  Highly, highly recommended.  (Hi, @John Carson!)
‚Ä¢	My laugh-at-myself moment in this puzzle: That longer-than-I‚Äôd-like-you-to-know period where I wondered, ‚ÄúEggplant?  People crack eggplants?  How do you crack an eggplant ‚Äì and why?‚Äù  I actually Googled ‚Äúeggplant cracking‚Äù.  Sigh.
‚Ä¢	In the box, a rare-in-crosswords five-letter semordnilap (LOOPS).
‚Ä¢	Also, the lovely abutting DIP and OARS.

Congratulations, Stacy and Ken, on your double debut.  Your puzzle got my brain going in many delectable directions.  Thank you!

Congratulations on
cracking the code and 
earning your debut!

Well done!üëç

Very lucky to have read about MASH recently or the two crossing 70s sitcom actors would‚Äôve spoiled the Monday for me. I wonder if those highly correlated clues ought to be separated early in the week, but maybe I ought to be watching some sitcoms from well before I was born.
What a lovely Monday puzzle. Congrats on your debuts! Thanks!
Found this way too obscure in parts

Note to self: in the NYT it‚Äôs EGGPLANT, not aubergine. That‚Äôs why it wouldn‚Äôt fit. Duh.

Good Monday puzzle, fairly straightforward once I remembered the above. TIL VIGODA, fortunately it came from the crosses. 

Can‚Äôt say I‚Äôve ever used/heard the phrase WHATS CRACKING. I was going for CooKING, but again, there was a misfit. Plus, how would I cook a CODE? And yes, I too am in the ‚Äòlike fingernails down a chalkboard‚Äô camp for that horrible KNUCKLE sound. Makes me squirm just to think about it.

Nice puzzle--I had filled everything but the one square at 51A/54D, and for some reason it took me a hot second (since I had no idea who the film director was). And that got me thinking about folks who complain that they aren't able to get clues right away--that is, without using the crosses. I wonder if it's more than just a resistance to what is the unique mechanic of the crossword: using the crosses to fill in where mere knowledge fails.

What I wonder is: how many solvers making this complaint are solving on their phones? Until recently, my morning routine consisted of the Bee, Wordle, and Strands on my phone then the xword on my laptop. I have added the mini, and it's a much different experience **because I can't see the crossing clues** as I'm solving. I've been solving a long time, so work fast on my laptop. For the mini, I'm forced to depend almost exclusively on my knowledge (and/or to retain the clues that are no longer displayed as I solve). I find this slows me down. Similarly, when I've done the big xword on my phone my times are much slower. 

I suspect that the interface of the phone app favors existing knowledge, where the interface on a laptop/browser better facilitates the strategy of using the crosses. I'd be interested to hear from people who make knowledge-based objections ("too obscure," "I didn't know X and so couldn't finish") about how they solve, and whether switching helps them...

Congratulations on the debut!  So much to admire:
Fresh idea for the theme! 
Minimum of three-letter entries!  
Novel Monday clues!

And now... (for future reference) please note:
Your True Solvers prefer the following:
FOUR Themers plus a Reveal....What about "NUTS and bolts?"
Photos on xwordinfo plus personal details in case any of us have marriageable offspring;
The addition of qualifiers such as "...but not any more" on clues such as the one for 30D.  Modern Times.
Thank you for your attention in these matters.
New PB despite some struggles with proper nouns. Good solid Monday. I appreciated 28D/60D. Congrats to the constructors on their debut!

Congrats to the constructors on their debut. I was not able to ‚Äúcrack‚Äù this one though, without looking up the name of the director at 54D. That whole bottom middle area had me stumped because I couldn‚Äôt figure out what CODE, EGG, and KNUCKLE had to do with each other and I had never heard the word LACUNA. Why was such an obscure word in a Monday puzzle? Of course, it‚Äôs probably just obscure to me. [Sigh] Nearly 8 minutes over my average today. üòû
Who was it, last week, that wanted to see baba ghanoush in a puzzle after we got the answer HUMMUS? I‚Äôm thinking of you!
Ellen? Funny? Must have missed that part‚Ä¶.

How could anyone on earth not know VIGODA and ALDA?!

How did you even solve the TV Guide crossword puzzles in the '70s?!



Lacuna matata!!

Was happy to see my favorite dip, but a bit perturbed at the overabundance of obscure names.  Monday is supposed to be the fun day but sometimes is more frustrating than Tuesday when there are too many names in key spotsüòÖ

In local news, there's a wild EMU loose on the Eastern Shore. It's believed to have escaped from a farm in Maryland, late last year, and has been running wild ever since. And at a top speed of 30 MPH, it's been covering a lot of ground. Residents are advised to keep their distance.

Good morning! Just another manic Monday...Congratulations to Ken and Stacy on their debut. Made for a cracking good time. Cool working in Abe VIGODA, who was also in The Godfather. (It was the smart move. Tessio was always smarter.)
nifty little natick with VIGODA and ALDA. fun puzzle otherwise but that's very odd
loved it!

You must be joking.  Only a KNUCKLEHEAD would say WHAT'S CRACKING.

(Or maybe an EGGPLANT DIP.)

Why is my Gold star streak for
Mondays only showing 3 weeks in a row when a look at the archive clearly indicates I have four weeks of Monday gold stars.   I work hard for those stars!

Emus like gold stars for dinner.
I hate to be *that* comedy nerd, but for 42 Down, ‚ÄúSaturday Night Live‚Äù segments are famously ‚Äúsketches‚Äù and *not* ‚Äúskit‚Äù(s).
SNL makes ‚Äúsketches,‚Äù not skits!

welcome back from your sickbed Sam.

We feed stray cats, raccoons and opossums. It is humorous to watch each animal patiently wait while the other dines. Seeing raccoons, cats and opossums all sitting around the feeding area is a celebration of diversity.

LACUNA required the firing of many little gray cels.

Thank you Ken and Stacy, do it AGAIN.

WHAT'S happening?
WHAT'S shaking?
WHAT'S cooking?
WHAT'S up?
WHAT'S going on?
Sure.

WHAT'S CRACKING????
Well, why not?

TIL that baba ganoush is made from eggplant. I had it classed with hummus in my mind.

And Steve L was correct last night, predicting that SKIT v sketch would be one of the common gripes today.

Great debut, Ken and Stacy.
Welcome back, Sam.
Applause and fanfare for all three of you.
Not sure where those extra H's came from for LA DI DA...

Like others have said, I don‚Äôt think I ever heard La-Di-Da spelled Lah-Di-Dah but thankfully the crosses made it pretty obvious. There were a few other questionable word uses especially for a Monday. If this  any indication of how the week will play out for crosswords it should be interesting‚Ä¶

In my 65 years, I‚Äôve never heard ‚Äòwhat‚Äôs cracking‚Äô.  
That said, break‚Äôs over and it‚Äôs time to ‚Äòget cracking‚Äô.

Anybody else with streaks that are showing up broken when they are NOT?

As someone else said, I work hard and faithfully for all those gold stars and don't appreciate it when they are incorrectly withheld!

This has happened to me at least 3 times in the last 2 months and I'm getting seriously fed up. (Pacifist though I am, I'd still like to crack somebody over the head to get them to correct this obvious programming glitch.)
VIGODA crossing IMPEI??? Painnnnful to me personally. Way over my Monday average :(
Zipped through in 4:44.  Thanks for a nice start to Monday!
For Ken's mother - I used to find Mondays too easy also, and then I read that Rex Parker did them Downs Only, and now I look forward to doing them that way.

Excellent puzzle. Tell the constructor's mother to do those "too easy" Mondays via downs only. That's what I do. And today's had the extra crunchiness of requiring a few peeks at the acrosses to finish. SHARD v SHERD needs one to know if LUNE or LUNA. And I rarely know actors or directors, so even having __GODA wasn't enough.(Unless Alda, Guiness, Redgrave, Mirren, Densch, Hugh Grant, Jennifer Lawrence, Wayne, Newman, Denzel Washington, Hanks, Keira Knightley, both Hepburns, Bogart, Bergman, Mae West, Sellers.) Blanking on a few other favorites, though, like the  star  of "Hopscotch".
And now I need a Brit to remind me of that married couple that did classic theater for years.
Crossing VIGODA with IMPEI and ALDA is a party foul.

Nice debut Stacy and Ken!  Great theme and clues.  

There's lah-di-dah, 
la-di-da,
lah-de-dah
and Lottie Dottie DA.
Upper left corner proper nouns were rough for me even after working the crosses. Otherwise enjoyed the puzzle
Glad you‚Äôre back and feeling good again. Love your intros!

Surprisingly, I found this very doable, despite never having heard of VIGODA, (or Barney Miller) or IM PEI (at first I thought the first name was Im) or Fuzzy Bear.
I found quite a few clues were exceptionally easy, like OSLO, LADS, HAIKU. 
Lovely jubbly!
Sometimes being old pays off, I guess. Three names in the top middle that bothered a lot of people were sort of automatic for me. Now if they had been rock stars or in current movies...

Re today's column, I'm fairly certain that STP is a brand of motor oil additive and not motor oil.  Today's puzzle was a fun little Monday, although, LACUNA made me look twice at all of the crosses.  TIL an unfilled space is a LACUNA.
>10 proper names... 20 proper nouns... another version of trivia disguised as nytxw
A fun, quick solve, with a rarity for a Monday puzzle - LACUNA was new to me, and I had to finish off the puzzle solving it via crossing answers. Nice debut!

Prefacing a clue with ‚Äòslangy‚Äô does not make the answer a thing. Maybe WHATS CRACKING is a colloquial phrase but it has never, for my dime, been a thing anywhere; and I‚Äôve been around the block once or thrice.
Where's the setting for NEVER sending me an email when a post goes live?  Pestering the most frequent posters with spam email seems to be the worst way to reward them.
I really enjoyed this one! The theme was very cute, and I learned a new word from 47D. A very good Monday puzzle!

LACUNA comes directly from the Latin: a diminutive of *lacus* ("lake"), it literally means "pond," "puddle," but also "gully, "hollow," "cave"--in other words, any depression in which water is likely to accumulate (so, not a Hobbit-hole). 

But more importantly, Lacuna, Inc., is the company at the center of one of my all-time fave films, *Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind*.

1d, 2d, 3d all being trivia was mean :< i guess 1d would maybe be more known among americans, but still feels annoying when a corner becomes almost completely across entries because the downs give you nothing
This one only made sense if you‚Äôre over the age of 50 tbh. I didn‚Äôt understand any of the proper noun references except the locational ones. Pretty hard for a Monday.

Was zipping along and then drew blanks in the due south. RIAN was unknown, and LACUNA was not in the Monday portion of my crossword brain, and had to be loaded from some deeper region. Even SHAM was slow in coming, as was the revealer itself. 

Everything fell into place eventually, but not until the 12:30 mark. LAHDIDAH seems an odd spelling, but I suppose it's as good as any other.
Can somebody please explain to me how the clue "brother" yields the answer "Ado"?
Congrats, Stacy and Ken, on a terrific debut. It was a lot more fun than Monday puzzles often are, with extra layers to discover. I‚Äôll be watching for your names in future.
5D/23A crossing had me inputting every letter, only thing keeping me from a sub 5m time

In addition to his frequent appearances in crossword puzzles, I. M. Pei also had a stunning career in architecture, designing buildings that many of you have visited. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/I._M._Pei A friend an I were in Paris and saw the Louvre Pyramid under construction. The escalator that led to the subsurface entrance had just been installed and the workmen were about to test it. I asked if we could be the first to ride it, and they said no, it was only for disabled people. I pointed at my friend and said, "She limps!" (raised eyebrows from my friend). They laughed, shrugged, and down we went, the first ever to ride it. I had hoped for our names on a plaque, but nothing.

I did not care for 27D.  
It insists upon itself. 
(üòÅ)
13D made me smile out loud. Yes, I can do that. A lovely way to clue Yoko, and a very enjoyable Monday puzzle.
Loved it!  All the things that can be cracked made me smile.  Thanks to you both and congrats on your debut...

WHATSCRACKIN', you ask? 

Well, for kicks, I asked my A1 sauce to write a HAIKU about Abe Vigoda. 

I wasn't impressed, but I did give myself a few chuckles out of it. 

This is why I never use A1. Also, I don't typically eat steak.
Steve Martin is NOT a member of Mensa.

Welcome back, Sam!
Thanks to Ken and Stacy too--this was a ton of fun for a Monday! I especially loved VIGODA, ALDA, and LACUNA -- no rhyme intended! I suppose that makes me old too!
Hung on FIVE crossing proper nouns.  What an awful puzzle.

üôãüèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Yep, that's me, one of the old-timers who thought ALDA and VIGODA were gimmes! 

I'm trying to remember if I first learned LACUNA from Commander Data in Star Trek: The Next Generation ("Interface"), or if I'd known what it was before then...
What's crackin? None of Ellen's jokes. Otherwise, excellent Tuesday pozzle!
Naticked on V_GODA/_MPEI and S_P/_ERI. Had to guess until I got them.

Having recently celebrated a (sub-interstate) speed limit birthday, I'm loving the comments. Does anyone else remember all the times we lost Tessio and Fish? (Also, marriage goals with Bernice.) The decades-long history of the Abe Vigoda death hoax https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/arts-and-entertainment/wp/2016/01/26/the-decades-long-history-of-the-abe-vigoda-death-hoax/
25D should have had an italicized funny followed by DeGeneres? As this clue was clearly a joke.

Y‚Äôall, a dap is not the same thing as a fist bump. Woulda been really helpful to have a Black person proofread this.  

At best, you could say a simple fist bump at one point early in the origin of the practice could‚Äôve constituted a dap. But they were often much more complex and what I think is the most common one used now involves clapping the hands together, reorienting until you‚Äôre linked by the the fingers rather than palms, and pulling away. Leaning in and patting on the back is often added too. A fist bump might be incorporated but it isn‚Äôt necessary. And regardless, it‚Äôs reductive to the point of inaccuracy! Daps originate among Black soldiers as a code to indicate kinship, respect, and safety, and they‚Äôre still used to show that, particularly amongst Black men but expanded to other groups too, in greetings and goodbyes.
@Lewis RERUN was a particular favorite of mine
I'm sorry about the repeat posting.  That first post didn't show up!

Lewis,

Your first try did show up a few minutes late. Perhaps someone made the emus an offer they couldn't refuse.
@Lewis these were inspired, but 4 and 5 drove me insane, both were such "light bulb (moments)"

@Lewis


I've been having issues with delayed posts, too, and I know a few others have had problems, too. It's hard to know what to do: post again, or wait it out. I wish those emus (and their programmers) would get it together!
@elizabeth and I was absolutely shocked (!) when VIGODA popped into my brain as the answer. At my age it's quite a relief when that happens. I almost felt like I should apply to MENSA.
@K Barrett For some reason the name VaGODA sounded right, but was Naticked with aMPEI. A little odd for a Monday.
@Steve L You forgot the surfeit of proper nouns
@Steve L I'm just here to see who else was annoyed by the SNL clue. :)

@Steve L

@Steve L 

Fuzzy because we just went through this only a few weeks ago.

@Steve L 

I'm out of the loop on this. What's wrong with Fuzzy Wuzzy?

@Beth

I also didn't know, but youve prompted me to look it up.
Google "fuzzy wuzzy offensive" and all will be revealed. 

I've been innocently referring to my fuzzy pants, fuzzy coat, and fuzzy throw as "fuzzy wuzzy" without ever realizing it was inappropriate. 
Live and learn.

@sotto voce

Yikes!! I had no idea!!!

@Beth 

Of course, no one knows that anymore, but it's still somehow a big no-no.

@Vaer
Bzzt!
If you agree that Morse Code is "dit-dah" combinations, you lose the LAH-ti-DAH argument.
Although some Art is DADA

@Steve L et al

If we're referencing the Rudyard Kipling poem, be reminded that scornful superiority must bow to the fact that "Fuzzy-Wuzzy" indeed "broke the British square".... an extraordinary battlefield feat.

@Steve L
I have never found ELLEN DeGeneres to be funny. Terrible clue!

@Grant
Are you saying that because you don't find her funny, no one should find her funny?  I think there's pretty good evidence that that isn't true.

I was hoping that someone would complain about her inclusion in this puzzle given the accusations of abuse against members of her staff.
Then I could point out that being included in the puzzle should not be confused with an endorsement of someone's life.

@Vaer
Spelling onomatopoeias is always tricky (and arbitrary.
Almost as tricky as spelling "onamatopoieia".
Is "Lah-dee-dah" even an onomotopoia?

Well, PHOOEY!

@Steve L

The skit/sketch distinction makes me laugh.

@MOL
 I'm not sure what you're talking about,  but I'm talking about what Annie Hall says.

@The X-Phile
If that had been the snarky theme of this thread, I would have called out ALEC Baldwin, who killed somebody. Has he been back on SNL since that happened? In a SKIT, maybe? I don't pay much attention to celebrities, but I do know that ELLEN has decamped for Britain.

@Grant

Shoot one person to death and all of a sudden people are calling you a murderer.  It's hard to be a millionaire-celebrity.

I "liked" ALEC Baldwin, to the extent that one likes any celebrity, based on his appearances on "Comedians in Cars Getting Coffee" (and his being recorded on an answering machine calling his then 11-year-old daughter a "rude, thoughtless, little pig").
Then he became a quizmaster on Match Game, and I lost all respect for him.  And now he and his wife Hilaria are doing a reality show, which has been oddly reviewed.  Can someone lose more than "all" respect?
(And may I add that I'm mildly ashamed that I know this much about that man's life.)

@Bill 

I, too, noticed that

@Francis 

*meant to hit "Cancel", actually hit "Submit".

So I'll just go ahead an make the remark I intended to scuttle.

Many parts of calculus are way, way easier than trig or algebra, IMHO.
@Francis    Not when you haven't done any calculus since 1977.  I did use simple algebra at my job.

This all reminds me of a joke, and one I've probably told here.  But I'm going to modify it and repeat it anyway.

A calculus professor is teaching at the board.  At one point, he says "Now, it's obvious that..." and writes down another equation.

Then he stops, steps back from the board and stares at it.  He does this for five minutes.  Then he leaves the room entirely and is seen going to his office, pulling out some books and papers and scribbles madly for about 30 minutes.

Then he gets back up, walks back into the class room and says, "Yes, it's obvious."

@Times Rita

His family was not from Poland. Vigoda was born in Brooklyn, New York, on February 24, 1921, the son of Samuel Vigoda and Lena Moses, Jewish immigrants from Russia. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abe_Vigoda

@Barry Ancona 

Yeah, but some of the theories that pop up on Google do in fact link the mostly Jewish name Vigoda to the Polish word "wygoda" in some of its old meanings. Also, Russia ruled over much of what had been Poland for 150 years from the late 18th century up to 1918, so "from Russia" does not preclude links to Polish language or culture.

@Connor 

There will always be clues that are hard for younger people, and those that will be hard for older people.  But whereas the jury is still out as to whether, say, Jenna Ortega or Hannah Einbinder will ever reach the level of icon, Alan ALDA as Hawkeye Pierce in M*A*S*H already has.  M*A*S*H is a classic show that will never be outdated because it was already set in a historical period (Korean War) during its run (1970s-80s).  (It was stealthy commentary on the Vietnam War in its early run.)

Barney Miller was another top comedy of that era, although not reaching the pinnacle that M*A*S*H did, and Abe VIGODA was the consummate character actor on that show.  I think the humor would still hold up next to Brooklyn Nine Nine, say.

So, TL;DR:  Yes, you ought to be watching some sitcomes from well before you were born.

N.B. As a kid, my cohorts and I watched reruns of I Love Lucy and The Honeymooners...quality programming doesn't grow old.

@Ciaran
If you mean the W-9 (a tax document) --feel free to chip in and pay US income taxes.  We need all the help we can get.

@Mean Old Lady 

I did my Polish taxes this week. It took 5 minutes. I logged onto the central tax system where my tax report had been prepared by the government based on all my sources of income. I checked if everything was in order - it was. I clicked a single button and voila, taxes for 2024 were done.

@Andrzejz

How do they know all your sources of income?  I‚Äôm thinking if you‚Äôre self-employed, have rental properties, etc. 

In the US, you can take deductions for various things that the government is (so far) not likely to be aware of. 

My taxes used to be simple when I was just starting out: a salary, check a chart, boom, done. Now it‚Äôs so complicated that I have to have a guy for that. And I barely know what he did. 

The only thing that matters this year is that for once in the length of my memory, we‚Äôre getting a refund this year instead of paying. Woo hoo!

@Steve L 

Well, for example, I do in fact have a rental property. The law requires me to report having it, and to make monthly payments of the tax due. Then at the end of the year the system checks if I paid enough.

As for salaries and other remuneration, the person who hired you and pays you has to report it to the government so they know all about it. My father has many sources of income (for example, every year he gets paid for dozens of lectures he gives at various venues, and for many articles he publishes in the press), but the people hiring him and the government basically do all the paperwork for him. At the end of the fiscal year, all the data is in the system already. Before the online automated system was implemented, your employers would send you paperwork you had to work on yourself, and back then my parents did in fact hire an accountant to do it for them.

Some deductions one has to do on their own, yes, but they apply to few average people.

Things get more complicated for businesses I suppose, and maybe some self-employed people.

@Andrzej
This system of income taxes seems eminently sensible, but...
I suspect most Americans would object to such "prying" into one's finances by the federal government.
Although we apparently have no problem voluntarily giving much more information to Facebook, Amazon, Apple, TicToc, etc.

"The only thing that matters this year is that for once in the length of my memory, we‚Äôre getting a refund this year instead of paying. Woo hoo!"


Steve,
You're happy you over-withheld in 2024?
WHATEVS!

@Barry Ancona

We pay estimated tax every quarter. The refund we‚Äôre getting feels like a lot, but in reality, we overpaid by less than 10%. Every year, we kept missing the target and had to pay thousands in April. And because of that, the estimated tax payment kept going up and up, to the point that it seemed ridiculous. 

For once, we landed on a number that was close; our refund seems like a lot but is considerably less than most year‚Äôs balances due. Naturally, now the estimated payment goes down, and no doubt next year, it‚Äôll be too little. 

So I‚Äôm glad to be getting a little bit back, rather than paying a lot more so that I don‚Äôt lend the government a few dollars for a few months.

Steve,

You said you had "a guy for that." 
Maybe you need a different guy.

@David Reiffel
That‚Äôs an interesting thought. I first started regularly solving crosswords after watching the excellent ‚ÄúWordplay‚Äù documentary. Knowing that I could probably only solve Monday puzzles, I bought the NYT Monday-only books, where I had clues available at all times. Once I ‚Äúgraduated‚Äù myself to Wednesday puzzles, I decided to purchase the phone app and I think there was a difference in solving time not having the clues always visible. Of course, I can switch back and forth, but I wonder if there is something to this. I‚Äôm intrigued!

@David Reiffel

On my phone, tapping on the clue switches it to the orthogonal clue.  I use it all the time - it's no issue for me.  And, it's still easier than searching for the other clue in a list, which is what one does when solving manually.

@David Reiffel 

Interesting: I find the "desktop" interface so much less intuitive than the phone version! I will admit that for quite a while I didn't discover how best to use it on the phone, and found it frustrating. Perhaps you're in the same boat? 

1) I don't recall ever playing on my computer before starting with the phone, so I imagine it's partly what one is used to. 

2) I play in the mobile browser, so can't speak to the apps.

For me, it's great to be able to switch between across and down clues for the current square with just a tap of the clue bar.  ...If there are any keyboard shortcuts on the desktop, I don't know them, and moving around the clues & grid frustrate me. A lot. Plus, the necessary features are so much easier to reach on the phone: the rebus button bundled into the keyboard, the next/previous arrows -- and clues! -- right where you're already looking (instead of off to the side), the pause button a short distance above (instead of all the way at the top of the screen)... 

A few aspects of the phone interface continue to annoy me:
* Clue numbers are not displayed with the text! I imagine it was a design decision based on amount of space. This rarely affects the solve, but makes reviewing difficult!
* Zooming in and out only helps so much -- Sunday puzzles continue to tax my aging eyes! Lol. 

All that said, I am never one to make the kind of objections you mentioned...

@Mrs Jones jsut because you brought up architects...not as a critique...

Here are some architects people might want to be aware of...

Frank Lloyd Wright....Famous for Fallingwater...a house/museum in Pennsylvania.  A masterpiece.  AND the Guggenheim in NYC. AS well as a plethora of other buildings he designed which you can visit mostly in the US.

Ludwig Mies van der Rohe.   Said "less is more"  Modern mid century Architect

Frank Gehry lots of curvy playful buildings around the world.

Eero Saarinen the St Louis Arch and the TWA terminal/hotel at JFK.

IM Pei is known for lots of glass and struts...They Pyramid at the Louvre is one of his.

Buckminster Fuller liked geodesic domes.

Antonio Gaudi.   Barcelona...and La Sagrada Cathedral.

Christopher Wren helped rebuild London after the fire of 1666...Including St Paul's.

Speaking of London.   Things to know....1066 Norman Invasion.  1666 Great London Fire.   1966. Last time England won the World Cup.
